titlestmt.titleproper: Finding aid for the Wanda Coleman papers LSC.2282
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Kim Calder, June 16, 2016; machine-readable finding aid created by Caroline Cub√©.

publicationstmt.p: This record is made available under an Universal 1.0 Public Domain Dedication Creative Commons license.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2024-07-01 13:07:59 -0700.

physdesc.extent: (182 boxes, 2 record cartons, and 1 flat box)
(44 unprocessed record cartons, 4 unprocessed flat boxes, 1 unprocessed oversize record carton, 2 unprocessed oversize boxes, 1 unprocessed document box)

did.abstract: Wanda Coleman was born on November 13, 1946 and grew up in the Watts neighborhood of Los Angeles, CA. Coleman's poetry is widely anthologized and published, and her poetry collection Bathwater Wine received the 1999 Lenore Marshall Poetry Prize. In addition to her poetic career, Coleman was also successful across genres. She had a well-known column in the Los Angeles Times and won an Emmy for her writing on Days of Our Lives. The collection contains work produced by Coleman between 1960 and 2013, including manuscripts and drafts of her published poetry and prose, journalism, writing for film and television, and spoken word recordings, as well as many unpublished writings. In addition, there is a wealth of correspondence with major literary figures and institutions, activist materials, and ephemera relating to Coleman's professional and personal life.
did.physloc: Stored off-site. All requests to access special collections material must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.
did.langmaterial: Materials are primarily in English, some materials in Dutch and Italian.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. All requests to access special collections materials must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.
Originals in box 184 not available for consultation due to poor physical condition, use digitized versions only.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: CONTAINS UNPROCESSED DIGITAL/AUDIOVISUAL MATERIALS: Digital/audiovisual materials are not currently available for access and will require further processing and assessment. If you have questions about this material please email AskLSC@library.ucla.edu.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Property rights to the objects belong to UCLA Library Special Collections. All other rights, including copyright, are retained by the creators and their heirs. It is the responsibility of the researcher to determine who holds the copyright and pursue the copyright owner or his or her heir for permission to publish where The UC Regents do not hold the copyright.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Wanda Coleman papers (Collection 2282). UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, University of California, Los Angeles.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed by Kim Calder under the supervision of Jillian Cuellar and Courtney Dean in the Center for Primary Research and Training (CFPRT), 2015-2016.
Mold remediation was performed on Box 185.
Damaged material in Box 184 was digitized for preservation purposes.

Collections are processed to a variety of levels depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived user interest and research value, availability of staff and resources, and competing priorities. Library Special Collections provides a standard level of preservation and access for all collections and, when time and resources permit, conducts more intensive processing. These materials have been arranged and described according to national and local standards and best practices.

We are committed to providing ethical, inclusive, and anti-racist description of the materials we steward, and to remediating existing description of our materials that contains language that may be offensive or cause harm. We invite you to submit feedback about how our collections are described, and how they could be described more accurately, by filling out the form located on our website: Report Problematic Content and Description in UCLA's Library Collections and Archives.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Wanda Coleman was born on November 13, 1946 in Watts and raised in South Central Los Angeles. When she was eighteen, she married her first husband, Jerry Coleman, with whom she had two children, Anthony and Luanda Tunisia. Coleman retained custody of the children when she and Jerry divorced in 1969, and struggled to survive and write as a single mother. She worked as an editor for Players, a conscious Black gentleman's magazine, from 1972-1974, and in the mid 1970s, she moved to Hollywood, where she became an active participant in the spoken word and poetry communities, penning works for Studio Watts and becoming a fixture at Beyond Baroque in Venice. In 1977, she published a chapbook, Art in the Court of the Blue Fag, followed by a full-length collection of poems, Mad Dog Black Lady (1979) with Black Sparrow Press, beginning a publishing relationship that would last for over thirty years and produce twelve books in various genres. Her third child, Ian, with her second husband Stephen Grant, was born in 1978. Coleman was also an acclaimed performance artist known for her impactful readings. In the 1980s, her presence in the LA spoken word scene led her to collaborate with seminal punk figures such as Exene Cervenka (X) and Lydia Lunch, and she worked with New Alliance records to release a number of solo and split recordings. Coleman attended Valley Junior College and Cal State L.A., and went on to teach at UCLA extension, Cal State Long Beach, Naropa, and Loyola Marymount University, where she held the Fletcher Jones chair in literature and writing. Prolific across genres, Coleman wrote poetry, short stories, novels, nonfiction, and plays, as well as scripts for film and television, winning an Emmy for her work on on Days of Our Lives in 1976 and working as a featured columnist for the Los Angeles Times. Coleman is one of the most widely anthologized and published poets of her generation, appearing in prestigious collections such as Postmodern American Poetry: A Norton Anthology and The Oxford Anthology of African-American Poetry. Her poetry collection Bathwater Wine received the 1999 Lenore Marshall Poetry Prize, Mercurochrome: New Poems (2001) was a finalist for the National Book Award, and her honors include a Guggenheim, an NEA fellowship, and the Poetry Society of America's Shelley Memorial Award. With her husband of thirty years, poet and visual artist Austin Straus, she hosted "The Poetry Connexion" on KPFK from 1981-1994. She died November 22, 2013. In November of 2015, the Ascot branch of the Los Angeles public library in Watts, where Coleman spent many of her formative years reading and writing, was renamed the Wanda Coleman Branch in her honor.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The collection chronicles Coleman's entire career (1960-2013), and includes many materials that provide insight into her process, such as meticulously kept records of submissions, publications, and rejections; multiple drafts and revisions of poems, stories, and articles with Coleman's edits; correspondence with John Martin at Black Sparrow Press regarding major works; a wealth of correspondence with major literary figures such as E. Ethelbert Miller and Sesshu Foster; many activist materials; flyers and other ephemera related to Coleman's public performances and other "gigs"; teaching materials; photographs; recordings; and many unpublished writings including a novel, a collection of newer short stories, and screenplays.

list.item: Subseries 2.4: Spoken Word, TV, Film, and Theater, 1970-2011

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: Digital reproductions of materials in Box 184 are available for viewing in the Library Special Collections reading room.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Contains personal and professional letters and emails to and from Coleman, as well as correspondence and materials detailing her submissions process and rejections/acceptances. Includes letters to and from John Martin, her publisher at Black Sparrow Press, and correspondence with major figures such as Amiri Baraka, Sherman Alexie, Octavia Butler, Exene Cervenka, Cornelius Eady, Sesshu Foster, S.A. Griffin, Allen Ginsberg, C.S. Giscombe, Anna Halprin (San Francisco Dancers' Workshop), Terrance Hayes, bell hooks, Yusef Komunyakaa, Audre Lorde, Clarence Major, E. Ethelbert Miller, Ishmael Reed, Diane Wakoski, and Anne Waldman.

arrangement.head: Organization and Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series maintains original order. Coleman organized the bulk of her personal and professional correspondence alphabetically, but the latter part of the series includes correspondence not included within this alphabetical arrangement, ordered chronologically and by type. Correspondence with major individuals and institutions has been gathered throughout processing and is included within the alphabetical sequence.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements

SOME ITEMS IN THIS SERIES HAVE BEEN DIGITIZED. Please contact the reference desk for details on arranging access.

scopecontent.p: Includes letter to John Martin (Black Sparrow Press) regarding Will Alexander and correspondence with Jeffrey Renard Allen.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Contains correspondence to and from Coleman regarding her controversial 2002 review of Angelou's A Song Flew Up to Heaven, along with drafts of her essay on the public's response, "Black on Black: Fear and Reviewing in Los Angeles."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Coleman did all the secretarial work for her brother George Evans' A.R.T. workshop for high schoolers. She used the pseudonym "Joyce Grant," (a combination of her middle name and her second husband's last name).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Many drafts of published and unpublished works by Wanda Coleman: poetry, fiction, nonfiction, spoken word, film, television and theater writings, and juvenilia, as well as volumes edited by Coleman. Includes related correspondence and digital materials. Highlights include correspondence with John Martin at Black Sparrow Press regarding her publications there, many unproduced screenplays, and unpublished collections of poetry and short stories.

arrangement.head: Organization and Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series is broken into subseries by genre, and each is ordered chronologically. Within subseries 2.1-2.3 (poetry, fiction, nonfiction), published manuscripts lead the series, followed by unpublished manuscripts, then individual drafts.

SOME ITEMS IN THIS SERIES HAVE BEEN DIGITIZED. Please contact the reference desk for details on arranging access.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Published and unpublished collections of Coleman's poetry, as well as drafts of individual poems. The drafts, which appear and the end of the series, are organized chronologically and include both published and unpublished poems with Coleman's edits.. Includes related correspondence. Materials for Coleman's collection of poems Ostinato Vamps (2003) are not included.

did.unittitle: "Poetry, Race, and the Power to Change The World"
Spoken Word, TV, Film, and Theater

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Contains recorded material from New Alliance records including Coleman's projects with Exene Cervenka, Lydia Lunch, and Michelle T. Clinton; episodes written for popular television shows such as Days of our Lives (for which she won an Emmy), Starsky and Hutch, and Sanford and Son; multiple unproduced screenplays; and plays, including The Product, written in collaboration with Jim Woods of Studio Watts. Includes related correspondence.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: THIS SUBSERIES CONTAINS AUDIOVISUAL MATERIALS: Audiovisual materials in this collection will require assessment and possible digitization for safe access. To review these audiovisual materials, you must notify the UCLA Library Special Collections Reference Desk in advance of your visit.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Includes materials related to Coleman's spoken word projects with Exene Cervenka, Michelle T. Clinton, and Lydia Lunch; compilations "Black and Tan Club" and "Jazzspeak"; as well as solo recordings "Black Angeles," "Twin Sisters," "Black and Blue News," "Beserk on Hollywood Blvd." and "High Priestess of Word." Includes digital materials.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: Files contain nine 1/8 inch cassettes and one compact disc. Audiovisual materials in this collection will require assessment and possible digitization for safe access. To review these audiovisual materials, you must notify the UCLA Library Special Collections Reference Desk in advance of your visit.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: File contains one 1/8 inch audio cassette. Audiovisual materials in this collection will require assessment and possible digitization for safe access. To review these audiovisual materials, you must notify the UCLA Library Special Collections Reference Desk in advance of your visit.

scopecontent.p: Coleman won an Emmy for her writing on Days.

unittitle.title: Are You Listening To Me Sweetie?

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes episodes co-written with Christipher Joy for Starsky and Hutch and Sanford and Son.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Coleman developed this story as both a screenplay and a novel under these two titles.

did.unittitle: Operation Move: The Trial of Ramona Africa (research)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes Angel Street episode.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Screenplay drafts of Beulah Land, a mini-series about a 19th century Southern plantation and materials/correspondence relating to the Coalition Against the Airing of Beulah Land.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Early writings of Coleman's dating from 1961-1971 and a few more recent works of visual art by Coleman. Includes school notebooks containing class assignments, sketches and drawings; a small collection of periodicals, and early stories, poems, and essays.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes Coleman's piece "Emotional Blackmail," submitted to the Whitney Ray Johnson Exhibition, and some drawings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Includes correspondence, ephemera such as programs, flyers, and photographs, and other documentation relating to "gigs" such as readings and lectures, serving as a panelist for various awards and grants, her time as editor of Players Magazine, and teaching jobs. She kept much of this material in "PR" files, and also included is her correspondence with the Guy Joyce PR agency, who she employed for a short time to represent her. Of particular interest are the files from her time at Loyola Marymount University as the Fletcher Jones chair in literature and writing and her correspondence with legal advisors after the university chose not to continue her appointment.

arrangement.head: Organization and Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series is ordered chronologically. All teaching materials were kept together to maintain original order, and appear at the series' end.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: SOME ITEMS IN THIS SERIES HAVE BEEN DIGITIZED. Please contact the reference desk for details on arranging access.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes materials related to Coleman's plays The Product, Black Girl in Search of God (George Bernard Shaw adaptation) produced by Studio Watts; Ceremony of Us (collaboration between Studio Watts and Anna Halprin of the San Francisco Dancers' Workshop, in which Coleman performed); ephemera, and correspondence.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: THIS ITEM HAS BEEN DIGITIZED. Please contact the reference desk for details on arranging access.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Includes PR materials related to Mad Dog Black Lady. Folder 9 includes photographs by George Evans of Coleman at the Whisky-a-Go-Go, where she performed in 1982.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: THIS ITEM HAS BEEN DIGITIZED. Please contact the reference desk for details on arranging access.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Wanda Coleman held the appointment of Fletcher Jones Chair at LMU from 1994-1996, after which she was terminated. In addition to student work and course materials, evidence toward and correspondence regarding Coleman's desire to file a wrongful termination suit against the university is included.

did.unittitle: Loyola Marymount University (student essays on Coleman)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Includes Coleman's "clippings files," in which she collected newspaper articles; activist materials such as flyers and periodicals; Coleman's magazine collection; a small sample of her personal book collection and copies of some of her own published books; some periodicals in which Coleman was published; photos; and other ephemera such as her Emmy award certificate.

arrangement.head: Organization and Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series maintains original order. Coleman arranged her "clippings files" both by topic and chronologically.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: SERIES CONTAINS AUDIOVISUAL MATERIALS: Audiovisual materials in this collection will require assessment and possible digitization for safe access. To review these audiovisual materials, you must notify the UCLA Library Special Collections Reference Desk in advance of your visit.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes Coleman's master list of clippings files by topic.

scopecontent.p: Selected periodicals featuring Coleman's work.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Includes selected periodicals featuring Coleman and a CD recording of Coleman and other poets reading at Southern California venues (2011).

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: File contains one compact disc. Audiovisual materials in this file will require assessment and possible digitization for safe access. To review these audiovisual materials, you must notify the UCLA Library Special Collections Reference Desk in advance of your visit.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Box 182 includes copies of some of Coleman's published books: The Dicksboro Hotel (1989), African Sleeping Sickness (1993), Native in A Strange Land (1996), and The World Falls Away (2011). Both Boxes 181 and 182 contain a small sample of Coleman's personal book collection.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Box 180 includes Coleman's Emmy certificate and other awards; her birth certificate; Super Lotto records; and a piece of wall art. 183 includes plaques, awards, and a board game.
